question: Question_12_(b)
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problem.} Justify your answer and \textbf{show all
your work. Simplification of numerical answers is required.}.

Explain why you \emph{cannot} conclude that
$\displaystyle \sum_{n=2}^\infty \frac{n+\sin n}{1+n^2}$ diverges from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH101/April_2013/Question_12_(a)}{part
(a)} and the Integral Test.
sols:
If $\displaystyle f(x) = \frac{x+\sin x}{1+x^2}$, then its clear it is
positive, tends to 0, and agrees with the summands on the natural
numbers. So we should prove it is never eventually decreasing. Taking
the derivative,

\[\displaystyle 
f'(x) = \frac{(1+\cos x)(1+x^2)-2x(x+\sin x)}{(1+x^2)^2}\]

We want to show that \emph{$f$} is never eventually decreasing. For this,
it suffices to find a sequence \emph{x\textsubscript{n}} of values that
grow with no limit, and for which \emph{$f$'(x\textsubscript{n})} is
positive. How would be go about finding such a sequence? Let us look at
the enumerator more carefully. Our best bet to make
\emph{$f$'(x\textsubscript{n})} positive is to choose
\emph{x\textsubscript{n}} such that the positive term is maximal. This
is achieved when \emph{cos(x\textsubscript{n}) = 1}. In this case,
\emph{sin(x\textsubscript{n}) = 0} and we find that the enumerator
becomes
\emph{2(1+x\textsubscript{n}\textsuperscript{2})-2x\textsubscript{n}\textsuperscript{2}
= 2 \textgreater{} 0}. Hence, we choose $\displaystyle x_n = 2n\pi$ for
any integer \emph{n}, and double check that indeed the numerator
becomes:

\begin{align*}
& (1+\cos(2n\pi))(1+(2n\pi)^2)-2(2n\pi)((2n\pi)+\sin (2n\pi)) \\
= \ & 2(1+4n^2\pi^2)-8n^2\pi^2 \\
= \ & 2 > 0
\end{align*}

The denominator is always positive, so $\displaystyle f'(x_n) > 0$ for
these values of $\displaystyle x_n$, so that $\displaystyle f(x_n)$ is
increasing at these values of $\displaystyle x_n$. Since
$\displaystyle 2n\pi$ grows with no limit, $\displaystyle f(x)$ is never
eventually decreasing, and hence the integral test fails.
hints: What hypotheses are required for the Integral Test? Which one fails?

If $\displaystyle f(x) = \frac{x+\sin x}{1+x^2}$, then its clear it is
positive, tends to 0, and agrees with the summands on the natural
numbers. So prove it is never eventually decreasing.

It might be easiest to prove
$\displaystyle f(x) = \frac{x+\sin x}{1+x^2}$ is never eventually
decreasing by differentiating and using a differential calculus result.
